    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
In Washington
  today all eyes were on a former top White House aide who was sentenced to
  time behind bars. Former vice presidential chief of staff I. Lewis
  “Scooter” Libby was slapped with 30 months in prison and fined
  $250,000 for lying and hindering the CIA leak case investigation. Bob Orr
  will have the story.
 
An appeals court struck down a new U.S. policy against accidentally
  aired profanities on TV and radio. The decision noted that what’s
  considered vulgar language is now so common even President Bush uses it
  (remember what he told Tony Blair that Hezbollah should stop doing?). Now, a
  sudden slip of the tongue – even on air – will likely be excused.
  That could come as a relief to some broadcasters, but the FCC isn’t so
  thrilled, Nancy Cordes will report.
 
Meanwhile, our chief foreign correspondent Lara
  Logan is in Baghdad
  embedded with a unit that discovered what’s thought to be an al Qaeda
  dumping ground. She’ll report on what she’s seen and also show
  you new video of a massive attack on Iraqi insurgents.
 
Athletes could have a quicker new way to get up and
  running after joint injuries. Our Dr. Jon LaPook will report on a therapy
  that extracts a patient’s own blood platelets and puts them back in the
  injured area so they can help the body heal itself. 
 
Finally, Wyatt Andrews will report for Shades of America
  on groups of inner-city students who got a little help from their friends
  – to attend and graduate college. It is a scholarship program that
  stresses the importance of students’ “posse” as a support
  network through college – and it is having outstanding results.
 
I hope you’ll join us for these stories and
  more,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
